questions.text: A patient on lithium therapy developed hypertension. He was on thiazides for hypertension. After few days, he developed coarse tremors and other symptoms suggestive of lithium toxicity. Explain the likely mechanism of this interaction:

options.label: A
options.text: Thiazide inhibits the metabolism of lithium

options.label: B
options.text: Thiazides act as an add on drug to lithium

options.label: C
options.text: Thiazides increases the tubular reabsorption of lithium

questions.correct_answer: C. Thiazides increases the tubular reabsorption of lithium
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Thiazides increases the tubular reabsorption of lithium

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Thiazides: Hydrochlorothiazide is a diuretic (water pill) medicine used to treat hypertension (high blood pressure). This medicine reduces excess fluid levels in the body and treats edema (fluid overload) associated with heart, liver, kidney, or lung disease. Lithium: is an effective maintenance treatment for bipolar disorder. It acts as mood stabiliser and reduces the risk of suicide. However, evidence assessing the efficacy of lithium in the treatment of acute mania is less robust.

Table:

#MANTRA

questions.text: Which of the following drugs shown in the graph below has highest potency?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Drug A Drug A - at the minimum dose produces the required response and hence it has the highest potency.

Highyeild:

Potency – relative dose of a drug required to produce a particular effect. This is a drug response curve where dose is taken on X axis and the response of the drug is taken on Y axis. Potency is inversely proportional to dose. Potency of a drug can be determined by observing the X axis. More the graph is on the left side (means lesser the dose) required to produce the desired effect. Therefore more the potency of the drug, as less amount of drug is required to produce the desired effect.

questions.text: Resistance to the beta lactams is an alarming and growing phenomenon, in turn, a public health challenge. Therefore out of the following what is the main mechanism of b lactam resistance with b-lactamases:
questions.correct_answer: C. Breaks the structure of penicillin
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Breaks the structure of penicillin

Highyeild:

B lactamases are the enzymes secreted by the gram negative bacteria’s such as Klebsiella pneumonia, E. coli etc. which destructs the b lactam ring present in b- lactam antibiotics. B lactams are those drugs that contains the beta-lactam ring in their structure. These drugs acts by inhibiting cell wall synthesis and includes – Penicillins Cephalosporins Monobactams Carbapenems Mechanism of bacterial resistance to penicillin via beta lactamase is done by breaking of beta lactam ring of the penicillin drug Alteration of Penicillin Binding protein (PBPs)- MRSA Drug efflux- Chloramphenicol, Tetracycline Alteration in 50S ribosomes –Aminoglycosides

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B. Efflux systems function via an energy-dependent mechanism (active transport) to pump out unwanted toxic substances through specific efflux pumps. Some efflux systems are drug-specific, whereas others may accommodate multiple drugs with small multidrug resistance (SMR) transporters. Option D. Alternation of 50s ribosome structure- 50S is the larger subunit of the 70S ribosome of prokaryotes, i.e. bacteria and archaea. It is the site of inhibition for antibiotics such as macrolides, chloramphenicol, clindamycin, and the pleuromutilins. It includes the 5S ribosomal RNA and 23S ribosomal RNA.

Table:

#MANTRA

questions.text: Pegloticase is used for treatment of:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Chronic tophaceous gout

Highyeild:

Chronic Refractory Gout Pegloticase is a recombinant porcine-like uricase {Uricase is a hepatic enzyme that converts uric acid into allantoin} which is more easily excreted by the kidney because of its water-soluble compound. Drug indicated for the treatment of severe, treatment-refractory, chronic gout. This reduces the risk of precipitate formation and development of gout, since allantoin is five to ten times more soluble than uric acid. Rasburicase is used in Hyperuricemia secondary to anticancer therapy

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A. Ankylosing spondylosis is an immune disease. The disease is more common and more severe in men. It often runs in families. Early symptoms include back pain and stiffness. These problems often start in late adolescence or early adulthood. Over time, ankylosing spondylitis can fuse your vertebrae together. Option B. Calcium pyrophosphate dihydrate (CPPD) crystal deposition disease, also known as pseudogout and pyrophosphate arthropathy, is a rheumatologic disease which is thought to be secondary to abnormal accumulation of calcium pyrophosphate dihydrate crystals within joint soft tissues. Option D. Refractory rheumatoid arthritis disease i s defined as failure to attain a predefined target, which is now accepted to be remission or, at least, a low disease activity state. Despite the enthusiastic progresses in the field of rheumatoid arthritis pharmacotherapy, few patients are still reaching sustained remission.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a prokinetic?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Diphenoxymethane A prokinetic agent (also gastro prokinetic agent, gastrokinetic agent or propulsive) is a type of drug which enhances gastrointestinal motility by increasing the frequency or strength of contractions , but without disrupting their rhythm. Prokinetic drug increases gastric emptying, relax pylorus, increases the tone of LES Examples— d2 antagonist – metoclopramide Domperidone 5HT4 agonist –cisapride, prucalopride Motilin receptor agonist – macrolides

Highyeild:

Prokinetic drugs Domperidone: D, antagonist Chemically related to haloperidol but pharmacologically related to metoclopramide Has lower ceiling antiemetic and prokinetic actions Poorly crosses BBB Rare extra pyramidal side effects Given with levodopa or bromocriptine to counteract their dose limiting emetic action

Table:

#MANTRA

questions.text: A female developed pain and insect crawling like sensation on legs at night which is relieved by shaking her legs. Which of the following is drug of choice for this condition?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pramipexole

Highyeild:

The diagnosis in the above condition is restless leg syndrome. Pramipexole is a non ergot D2 agonist used in treatment of Parkinson’s disease and also used in restless leg syndrome.

questions.text: Fluoroquinolone contraindicated in liver disease is?:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pefloxacin Fluoroquinolones eliminated in bile and not safe in liver failure are Pefloxacin Moxifloxacin Trovafloxacin

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A. Levofloxacin is an antibiotic, used in the treatment of bacterial infections in adults and children (>6months age). It is also used in treating infections of the urinary tract, nose, throat, skin and lungs (pneumonia). It cures the infection by stopping the further growth of the causative microorganisms. Option C. Ofloxacin -is an antibiotic that helps treat bacterial infections. It is used in treating infections of the urinary tract, nose, throat, skin and soft tissues, and lungs (pneumonia). It cures the infection by stopping the further growth of the causative bacteria. Option D. Lomefloxcin is an antibiotic, used in the treatment of bacterial infections. It is also used in treating infections of the urinary tract, nose, throat, skin and soft tissues and lungs (pneumonia). It prevents the bacterial cells from dividing and repairing, thereby killing them.

questions.text: At a high altitude of 3000 m, a person complains of breathlessness. All of the following can be used for management of this person except:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Intravenous digoxin At a high altitude like 3000m - high altitude pulmonary edema (HAPE) develops which is a non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema while IV digoxin is given in cardiogenic pulmonary edema.

Highyeild:

Treatment of high altitude illness – Advice immediate descent of at least 610m If descent is not possible then use hyperbaric chamber plus give oxygen to maintain the saturation of more than 90 percent +give pharmacological therapy like acetazolamide, dexamethasone etc.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option. D. Actezolamide is a medicine used to reduce pressure in the eyes. This pressure can be caused by or lead to an illness called glaucoma. If the pressure in your eye is too high it can damage your sight. Acetazolamide works by decreasing the amount of fluid inside the eye.

questions.text: A patient with diabetes and COPD developed post-operative urinary retention. Which of the following drugs can be used for short term treatment to relieve the symptoms of this person?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Tamsulosin Bethanechol is a muscarinic cholinomimetic, which acts at cholinergic receptors in the smooth muscle of the urinary bladder. It increases the tone of the detrusor urinary muscle, producing an increase in the intravesical pressure and therefore relieves the acute retention but bethanecol also leads to bronchospasm via M3 receptors present in lungs Tamsulosin is a selective α 1 receptor antagonist that has preferential selectivity for the α 1A receptor in the prostate versus the α 1B receptor in the blood vessels. When alpha 1 receptors in the bladder neck, the prostate, the ureter, and the urethra are blocked, a relaxation in smooth muscle tissue results. This mechanism decreases resistance to urinary flow and releases urinary retention and also it doesn’t leads to bronchospasm. Therefore, Tamsulosin is a better answer than Bethanechol.

questions.text: Drug of choice for invasive aspergillosis:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Voriconazole

Highyeild:

Voriconazole New triazole Structure much more like fluconazole than ketoconazole or itraconazole, thus, very bioavailable orally, but hepatic metabolism (CYP2C9 and CYP3A4) and much higher protein binding, shorter T1/2 (6 h) Fungistatic Activity against Candida (including C. kruseii and C. glabrata) and Aspergillus spp., but also against Crypto, Histo, Cocci, Blasto, and some ‘oddball' fungi (P. boydii, some Fusarium spp.) Invasive aspergillosis (IA) causes very high morbidity and mortality among the most severely immunosuppressed, especially those with profound qualitative or quantitative neutropenia. The preferred treatment of primary IA is voriconazole Azoles interfere with the synthesis of ergosterol found in the fungal cell membrane, whereas Polyenes -- such as amphotericin B -- interfere with ergosterol function. The mechanism of action of voriconazole, similar to that of all azole agents, is inhibition of cytochrome P450 (CYP 450)–dependent 14α-lanosterol demethylation, which is a vital step in cell membrane ergosterol synthesis by fungi.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A. Posaconazole belongs to a group of medicines called antifungals. It works by stopping the growth of fungus and is used to treat fungal infection. It kills fungi by destroying the fungal cell membrane. Option C. Liposomal AMB is a unique lipid formulation of amphotericin B that has been used for nearly 20 years to treat a broad range of fungal infections. While the antifungal activity of amphotericin B is retained following its incorporation into a liposome bilayer, its toxicity is significantly reduced. Option D. Caspofungin has been effective in treating fungal infections caused by Aspergillus and Candida It is a member of the echinocandin family, a new class of antifungal agents with broad spectrum of activity against all Candida species. In comparison to treatment with either fluconazole or Amphotericin B, all three drugs in this class have been demonstrated to be highly effective or superior in well-defined clinical settings including invasive Candida infections

questions.text: Which of the following antihypertensive drug is avoided in patients with high serum uric acid levels?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hydrochlorothiazide Hydrochlorothiazide is a diuretic medication often used to treat high blood pressure and edema due to fluid buildup. Hyperuricemia is one of the side effect of hydrochlorothiazide. Thiazide causes hyperuricemia by the following mechanisms - Hydrochlorothiazide acts by inhibiting NaCl and water absorption in DCT because of which osmotic pressure decreases in the body and because uric acid is osmotic in nature which leads to compensatory reabsorption of uric acid in the body. Uric acid is absorbed in PCT via a pump URAT1/OAT1 and thiazides also acts via same transporter. Therefore, Thiazides competitively block the excretion of uric acid and causes hyperuricemia.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B. Enalapril belongs to a group of medicines known as ACE inhibitors. It is widely used to treat high blood pressure and heart failure and may be prescribed after a heart attack. It also lowers the chances of having a heart attack or stroke. Option C. Prazosin belongs to a class of medicines called as alpha-blocker. It is used to treat high blood pressure and lower your risk of having a heart attack or stroke. It may also be used to treat heart failure and mild enlargement of the prostate gland in men. Option D. Atenolol belongs to a group of medicines called beta-blockers. It is used to treat high blood pressure (hypertension), angina (heart-related chest pain), irregular heart rhythms (arrhythmia). It also helps to prevent future heart attacks and stroke and to prevent migraine.

questions.text: Which of the following antimicrobials should not be given to a chronic asthmatic patient managed on theophylline therapy?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Erythromycin Erythromycin increases the serum concentration of theophylline because it erythromycin is an enzyme inhibitor and increases theophylline levels and causes toxicity.

Highyeild:

MOTILIN RECEPTOR AGONISTS Erythromycin ▸ Effect on gastroparesis - two pathways activating motilin receptors on cholinergic neurons & muscle ▸ Most effective intravenous prokinetic agent in acute setting initial management of hospitalized patients with diabetic gastroparesis ▸ Rapid development of tolerance is seen - By 4 weeks of oral treatment Drawbacks - Potential to induce abdominal cramps, nausea & vomiting & to slow small intestinal transit

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B. Cefotaxime is an antibiotic used to treat a number of bacterial infections in human, other animals and plant tissue culture. Specifically in humans it is used to treat joint infections, pelvic inflammatory disease, meningitis, pneumonia, urinary tract infections, sepsis, gonorrhea, and cellulitis. Option C. cotrimoxazole Sulfamethoxazole+Trimethoprim is a combination medicine that is used to treat various types of bacterial infections such as pneumonia, bronchitis, infections of urinary tract, ear, and abdomen. It prevents the growth of microorganisms to cure the infection. Option D. Amoxycillin is an antibiotic medicine with versatile actions. It can treat a multitude of bacterial infections including those of the ears, eyes, nose, sinus, tonsils, tooth, throat, lungs, skin, gastrointestinal tract, and urinary tract. It may also be effective against peptic ulcer disease.

questions.text: A person was given a muscle relaxant that competitively blocks nicotinic receptors. Which of the following drug is used for reversal of muscle relaxation after surgery?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Neostigmine Neostigmine is a parasympathomimetic drug which acts by inhibiting acetylcholinesterase enzyme and therefore increases the concentration of Ach in the synapse and reverses the effect of muscle relaxant which competitively blocks the nicotinic receptor. Physostigmine is not used as it is lipid soluble and therefore it will cause CNS side effects while Neostigmine is lipid insoluble.

Highyeild:

Neostigmine (Prostigmin) Therapeutic uses ► Myasthenia gravis ► Reversal of nondepolarizing neuromuscular blockade Used postoperatively Treatment of overdose Likely to elicit substantial muscarinic responses May need to administer atropine (muscarinic antagonist)

questions.text: Anti-glaucoma drug that acts by increasing uveoscleral outflow is :
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Latanoprost Latanoprost ophthalmic is used to treat glaucoma (a condition in which increased pressure in the eye can lead to gradual loss of vision) and ocular hypertension (a condition which causes increased pressure in the eye). Latanoprost is in a class of medications called prostaglandin analogs. It lowers pressure in the eye by increasing the flow of natural eye fluids out of the eye.

Highyeild:

Drugs used in Glaucoma DECREASE AQUEOUS PRODUCTION OCULAR BETA BLOCKERS 1. Timolol (Topical) 2. Betaxolol (Beta) 3. Levobunolol (BI...) 4. Carteolol (...ckers) ALPHA₂-SELECTIVE AGONIST 1. Apraclonidine 2. Brimonidine CARBONIC ANHYDRASE (CA) INHIBITORS 1. Acetazolamide 2. Brinzolamide 3. Dorzolamide (Sulphonamide derivatives) INCREASE AQUEOUS OUTFLOW INCREASE TRABECULAR OUTFLOW INCREASE UVEOSCLERAL OUTFLOW NONSELECTIVE ALPHA AGONIST 1. Epinephrine 2. Dipivefrine - prodrug of epinephrine PROSTAGLANDIN (PGF20) ANALOGUES 1. Latanoprost 2. Bimatoprost 3. Tafluprost CHOLINOMIMETIC DRUGS 1. Pilocarpine-direct 2. Physostigmine-indirect 3. Echothiophate-indirect

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B. Timolol is a beta-blocker is used to treat elevated intraocular pressure (high pressure inside the eye) in people with ocular hypertension or open angle glaucoma. It lowers the pressure in the eye by decreasing the production of fluid and reduces the risk of vision loss. Option C. pilocarpine is used in the treatment of dry mouth after radiotherapy of head and neck cancer. It works by stimulating the body to increase production of saliva, tears, sweat, digestive juices and other secretions. This makes speaking and swallowing easier. Option D. Dorzolamide is a medicine used to reduce pressure in the eyes. This pressure can be caused by or lead to an illness called glaucoma. If the pressure in your eye is too high it can damage your sight. Dorzolamide works by decreasing the amount of fluid inside the eye.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with Rheumatoid arthritis was on medications. After 2 years, he developed blurring of vision and was found to have corneal opacity. Which drug is most likely to cause this?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Chloroquine Chloroquine causes bulls eye maculopathy, so patient will have blurring of vision and also chloroquine causes corneal deposits which is responsible for corneal opacity and blindness

Highyeild:

Indications Chloroquine is drug of choice for malaria It completely cures sensitive falciparum disease, but relapses in vivax and ovale are not prevented. Other uses Extra intestinal amoebiasis Rheumatoid arthritis

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A. Sulfasalazine is used in the treatment of certain joint diseases and inflammatory bowel diseases. It slows down the progression of the disease and controls the symptoms of the disease. Option C. methotrexate is a chemotherapy agent and immune-system suppressant. It is used to treat cancer, autoimmune diseases, and ectopic pregnancies. Types of cancers it is used for include breast cancer, leukemia, lung cancer, lymphoma, gestational trophoblastic disease Option D. Leflunomide is used in the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis and psoriatic arthritis. It helps in slowing down the progression of the disease and provide relief from pain, swelling, and redness.

questions.text: A boy is planning to travel by bus. Which of the following drug can be used to prevent motion sickness in this person?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Promethazine Promethazine is an H1 receptor blocking agent. In addition to its antihistaminic action, it provides clinically useful sedative and antiemetic effects.

Highyeild:

Common forms Motion sickness can be constantly observed in everyday life: Car sickness Sea Sickness Air Sickness Nausea when watching 3D movies Affecting 25% to 40% percent of population

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B. Cetrizine is a second-generation antihistamine used to treat allergic rhinitis (hay fever), dermatitis, and urticaria (hives). It is taken by mouth. Effects generally begin within thirty minutes and last for about a day. Option C. Loratidine belongs to a group of medicines called antihistamines. It is used in the treatment of various allergic conditions. It relieves symptoms like itching, swelling and rashes Option D. Fexofenadine belongs to a group of medicines called antihistamines. It is used to treat various allergic conditions such as hay fever, conjunctivitis and some skin reactions such as eczema, hives, and reactions to bites and stings. It relieves watery eyes, runny nose, sneezing, and itching.

questions.text: Which of the following antiarrhythmic drug is contraindicated in a patient with interstitial lung disease?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Amiodarone

Highyeild:

Amiodarone is a primarily a class III antiarrhythmic. Amiodarone works primarily by blocking potassium rectifier currents that are responsible for the repolarization of the heart during phase 3 of the cardiac action potential. Amiodarone causes pulmonary fibrosis and there is an increase risk of pulmonary fibrosis in a patient with pre-existing lung disease like pneumonia, pneumoconiosis, ILD etc. which is highly fatal. Therefore patients on Amiodarone need regular monitoring of PFT and Chest X-RAY. DOC for treatment of drug induced pulmonary fibrosis is- prednisolone

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B. sotalol is used to treat various types of serious irregular heartbeat (arrhythmia) such as fibrillation and tachycardia. It is an anti-arrhythmic type of medicine and rapidly restores your heart to a steady and regular rhythm. Option C. Quinidine is a class IA antiarrhythmic agent used to treat heart rhythm disturbances. It is a diastereomer of antimalarial agent quinine, originally derived from the bark of the cinchona tree. The drug causes increased action potential duration, as well as a prolonged QT interval. Option D. Lignocaine also known as lignocaine and sold under the brand name Xylocaine among others, is a local anesthetic of the amino amide type. It is also used to treat ventricular tachycardia. When used for local anaesthesia or in nerve blocks, lidocaine typically begins working within several minutes.

questions.text: Which of the following is a late inward sodium channel blocker?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Ranolazine Ranolazine inhibits persistent or late inward sodium current (I Na ) in heart muscle in a variety of voltage-gated sodium channels. Inhibiting that current leads to reductions in intracellular calcium levels. This in turn leads to reduced tension in the heart wall, leading to reduced oxygen requirements for the muscle.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A. Ivabradine- Ivabradine is a heart-rate-lowering agent that acts by selectively and specifically inhibiting the cardiac pacemaker current (I f ), a mixed sodium-potassium inward current that controls the spontaneous diastolic depolarization in the sinoatrial (SA) node and hence regulates the heart rate. Option C. Trimetazidine inhibit β-oxidation of free fatty acid (FFA). Option D. Fasudil- is a selective RhoA/Rho kinase (ROCK) inhibitor. ROCK induces vasoconstriction by phosphorylating the myosin-binding subunit of myosin light chain (MLC) phosphatase, thus decreasing MLC phosphatase activity and enhancing vascular smooth muscle contraction.
